string: ACT I
SCENE I. London. A street.
Enter GLOUCESTER, solus
GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Now is the winter of our discontent
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And now, instead of mounting barbed steeds
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And that so lamely and unfashionable
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Have no delight to pass away the time,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Unless to spy my shadow in the sun
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And descant on mine own deformity:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To entertain these fair well-spoken days,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I am determined to prove a villain
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To set my brother Clarence and the king
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: In deadly hate the one against the other:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And if King Edward be as true and just
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: As I am subtle, false and treacherous,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: About a prophecy, which says that 'G'
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Clarence comes.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Enter CLARENCE, guarded, and BRAKENBURY

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: That waits upon your grace?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CLARENCE
speaker: CLARENCE

string: His majesty
speaker: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: CLARENCE

string: Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest
speaker: CLARENCE

string: As yet I do not: but, as I can learn,

speaker: CLARENCE

speaker: CLARENCE

speaker: CLARENCE

string: It follows in his thought that I am he.

speaker: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CLARENCE
speaker: CLARENCE

string: But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds
speaker: CLARENCE

string: That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.
speaker: CLARENCE

string: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant
speaker: CLARENCE

string: Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?
speaker: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Humbly complaining to her deity
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: If we will keep in favour with the king,

string: To be her men and wear her livery:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BRAKENBURY
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: I beseech your graces both to pardon me;

speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: How say you sir? Can you deny all this?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BRAKENBURY
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: He that doth naught with her, excepting one,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Were best he do it secretly, alone.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BRAKENBURY
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: What one, my lord?
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: BRAKENBURY
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
speaker: BRAKENBURY

string: CLARENCE
speaker: CLARENCE

string: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
speaker: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: We are the queen's abjects, and must obey.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CLARENCE
speaker: CLARENCE

string: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
speaker: CLARENCE

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Meantime, have patience.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CLARENCE
speaker: CLARENCE

string: I must perforce. Farewell.
speaker: CLARENCE

GLOUCESTER

He cannot live, I hope; and must not die
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.

string: I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

SCENE II. The same. Another street.
Enter the corpse of KING HENRY the Sixth, Gentlemen with halberds to guard it; LADY ANNE being the mourner
LADY ANNE

string: RATCLIFF
speaker: RATCLIFF

string: Not I, my lord.
speaker: RATCLIFF

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Then he disdains to shine; for by the book
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: He should have braved the east an hour ago
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliff!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: RATCLIFF
speaker: RATCLIFF

string: My lord?
speaker: RATCLIFF

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: The sun will not be seen to-day;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: More than to Richmond?  for the selfsame heaven
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Enter NORFOLK
NORFOLK
speaker: NORFOLK

string: Arm, arm, my lord; the foe vaunts in the field.
speaker: NORFOLK

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: And thus my battle shall be ordered:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Consisting equally of horse and foot;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Our archers shall be placed in the midst
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: They thus directed, we will follow
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: In the main battle, whose puissance on either side
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Shall be well winged with our chiefest horse.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: This, and Saint George to boot! What think'st thou, Norfolk?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: NORFOLK
speaker: NORFOLK

string: A good direction, warlike sovereign.
speaker: NORFOLK

string: This found I on my tent this morning.
speaker: NORFOLK

string: He sheweth him a paper
KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: [Reads]
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: 'Jockey of Norfolk, be not too bold,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: For Dickon thy master is bought and sold.'
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A thing devised by the enemy.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Go, gentleman, every man unto his charge
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Conscience is but a word that cowards use,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Devised at first to keep the strong in awe:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: March on, join bravely, let us to't pell-mell
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: His oration to his Army
What shall I say more than I have inferr'd?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Remember whom you are to cope withal;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A sort of vagabonds, rascals, and runaways,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A scum of Bretons, and base lackey peasants,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Whom their o'er-cloyed country vomits forth
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: To desperate ventures and assured destruction.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: You sleeping safe, they bring to you unrest;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: You having lands, and blest with beauteous wives,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: They would restrain the one, distain the other.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: And who doth lead them but a paltry fellow,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Long kept in Bretagne at our mother's cost?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A milk-sop, one that never in his life
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Felt so much cold as over shoes in snow?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Let's whip these stragglers o'er the seas again;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Lash hence these overweening rags of France,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: These famish'd beggars, weary of their lives;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Who, but for dreaming on this fond exploit,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: For want of means, poor rats, had hang'd themselves:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: If we be conquer'd, let men conquer us,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: And not these bastard Bretons; whom our fathers
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Have in their own land beaten, bobb'd, and thump'd,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: And in record, left them the heirs of shame.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Shall these enjoy our lands?  lie with our wives?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Ravish our daughters?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Drum afar off
Hark! I hear their drum.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Fight, gentlemen of England! fight, bold yoemen!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Draw, archers, draw your arrows to the head!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blood;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Enter a Messenger
What says Lord Stanley? will he bring his power?
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Messenger
speaker: Messenger

string: My lord, he doth deny to come.
speaker: Messenger

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: NORFOLK
speaker: NORFOLK

string: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh
speaker: NORFOLK

speaker: NORFOLK

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A thousand hearts are great within my bosom:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Advance our standards, set upon our foes
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Upon them! victory sits on our helms.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

SCENE IV. Another part of the field.
Alarum: excursions. Enter NORFOLK and forces fighting; to him CATESBY
CATESBY
speaker: CATESBY

string: Rescue, my Lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!
speaker: CATESBY

string: The king enacts more wonders than a man,
speaker: CATESBY

string: Daring an opposite to every danger:
speaker: CATESBY

string: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights,
speaker: CATESBY

string: Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.
speaker: CATESBY

string: Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
speaker: CATESBY

string: Alarums. Enter KING RICHARD III
KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: CATESBY
speaker: CATESBY

string: Withdraw, my lord; I'll help you to a horse.
speaker: CATESBY

string: KING RICHARD III
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Slave, I have set my life upon a cast,
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: And I will stand the hazard of the die:
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: I think there be six Richmonds in the field;
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Five have I slain to-day instead of him.
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
speaker: KING RICHARD III

string: Exeunt
SCENE V. Another part of the field.
Alarum. Enter KING RICHARD III and RICHMOND; they fight. KING RICHARD III is slain. Retreat and  flourish. Re-enter RICHMOND, DERBY bearing the crown, with divers other Lords
RICHMOND
speaker: RICHMOND

string: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: The day is ours, the bloody dog is dead.
speaker: RICHMOND

string: DERBY
speaker: DERBY

string: Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee.
speaker: DERBY

string: Lo, here, this long-usurped royalty
speaker: DERBY

string: From the dead temples of this bloody wretch
speaker: DERBY

string: Have I pluck'd off, to grace thy brows withal:
speaker: DERBY

string: Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.
speaker: DERBY

string: RICHMOND
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Great God of heaven, say Amen to all!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: But, tell me, is young George Stanley living?
speaker: RICHMOND

string: DERBY
speaker: DERBY

string: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town;
speaker: DERBY

string: Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
speaker: DERBY

string: RICHMOND
speaker: RICHMOND

string: What men of name are slain on either side?
speaker: RICHMOND

string: DERBY
speaker: DERBY

string: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Ferrers,
speaker: DERBY

string: Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.
speaker: DERBY

string: RICHMOND
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Inter their bodies as becomes their births:
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled
speaker: RICHMOND

string: That in submission will return to us:
speaker: RICHMOND

string: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: We will unite the white rose and the red:
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: That long have frown'd upon their enmity!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: What traitor hears me, and says not amen?
speaker: RICHMOND

string: England hath long been mad, and scarr'd herself;
speaker: RICHMOND

string: The brother blindly shed the brother's blood,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: The father rashly slaughter'd his own son,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: The son, compell'd, been butcher to the sire:
speaker: RICHMOND

string: All this divided York and Lancaster,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Divided in their dire division,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: O, now, let Richmond and Elizabeth,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: The true succeeders of each royal house,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: By God's fair ordinance conjoin together!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so.
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: With smiling plenty and fair prosperous days!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: That would reduce these bloody days again,
speaker: RICHMOND

string: And make poor England weep in streams of blood!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Let them not live to taste this land's increase
speaker: RICHMOND

string: That would with treason wound this fair land's peace!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Now civil wounds are stopp'd, peace lives again:
speaker: RICHMOND

string: That she may long live here, God say amen!
speaker: RICHMOND

string: Exeunt
